title: 107_hr1621
content: The Act may be cited as the "Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area Act of 2001". The Arabia Mountain area in Georgia contains diverse natural, cultural, and historical resources that are worthy of recognition and conservation. The best way to manage these resources is through partnerships between public and private entities. The Davidson-Arabia Mountain Nature Preserve protects various ecosystems and federally-protected plant species. The Panola Mountain State Conservation Park in DeKalb County, Georgia protects granite outcrop ecosystems, wetlands, and pine and oak forests. It also includes federally-protected plant species. Panola Mountain is a rare example of a pristine granite outcrop. The Miners Creek Preserve at South River has documented evidence of early human activity. The city of Lithonia, Georgia, along with Arabia Mountain and Stone Mountain, showcases the history of granite mining in Georgia. Klondike is eligible for designation as a National Historic District. The history of granite mining in Georgia and its impact on the United States. Klondike is eligible for National Historic District designation, while Lithonia has 2 structures listed on the National Register of Historic Places. The Act aims to recognize, preserve, and promote natural, cultural, and historical resources in the area including Arabia Mountain and Panola Mountain. The Act aims to develop and implement a program to protect, enhance, and interpret significant cultural, historical, and land resources in Georgia's heritage area, including DeKalb, Rockdale, and Henry counties. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. This section defines key terms such as "heritage area," "management entity," "management plan," "Secretary," and "State." SEC. 4. ARABIA MOUNTAIN NATIONAL HERITAGE AREA. This section establishes the Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area in Georgia. Establishment of Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area in Georgia, consisting of land in DeKalb, Rockdale, and Henry counties. Map available for public inspection. Arabia Mountain Heritage Area Alliance designated as management entity. Authorities and duties of the management entity outlined. The management entity for Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area in Georgia has the authority to make grants, hire staff, and enter contracts. They are responsible for developing and submitting a management plan that considers diverse interests within the area and gives priority to certain tasks. The management entity for Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area in Georgia must consider diverse interests and prioritize actions from the management plan, including assisting in resource preservation and encouraging land use policies. They are required to conduct public meetings quarterly on plan implementation. The management entity for Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area in Georgia must conduct public meetings quarterly on plan implementation and submit an annual report to the Secretary detailing accomplishments, expenses, and income. They are also required to make all records available for audit. The management entity for Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area in Georgia must conduct quarterly public meetings on plan implementation and submit an annual report to the Secretary detailing accomplishments, expenses, and income. They are also required to make all records available for audit, including those related to the expenditure of Federal funds and any matching funds. Federal funds under this Act cannot be used to acquire real property, but other Federal funds can be used for authorized purposes. SEC. 6. MANAGEMENT PLAN. The management entity must develop a plan for the heritage area based on the preferred concept from the Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area Feasibility Study. The plan should consider State and local plans, involve residents, public agencies, and private organizations, and include an inventory of resources in the area. The management plan for the heritage area must include an inventory of resources, provisions for protection and interpretation, an interpretation plan, and a program for implementation. The management plan for the heritage area must include an interpretation plan, a program for implementation, and a description of the management entity for submission to the Secretary for approval. The management entity must submit the management plan to the Secretary for approval within 3 years of the Act's enactment. Failure to submit the plan will result in a halt of additional funding. The Secretary will approve or disapprove the plan within 90 days of receiving it. The Secretary must approve or disapprove the management plan within 90 days of receiving it. If disapproved, the Secretary will provide reasons and allow for revisions to be submitted. After the Secretary approves a management plan, the management entity must periodically review and submit recommendations for revisions to the plan for approval within 90 days. The management entity must review and submit recommendations for revisions to the management plan to the Secretary for approval before implementing any proposed changes using funds from this Act. The Secretary may provide technical and financial assistance to the heritage area for developing and implementing the management plan, prioritizing actions that conserve natural, cultural, and historical resources. Authorization of appropriations is also included. Authorization of $10,000,000 for the Act, with a limit of $1,000,000 per fiscal year. Federal share not to exceed 50%. Secretary's authority to grant assistance terminates on September 30, 2016.
